AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hector Galvencio Paz-Ortega and Carlos E: Two Guatemalan citizens transported illegally by Juventino Mejia-Orosco
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hector Galvencio Paz-Ortega: Passenger, citizen of Guatemala, and relative of Juventino Mejia-Orosco
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Carlos Enrique Cruz-Morales: Passenger, citizen of Guatemala, and relative of Juventino Mejia-Orosco
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Juventino Mejia-Orosco, Hector Galvencio: Group involved in human smuggling operation
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Juventino Mejia-Orosco's van: vehicle used for transporting smuggled aliens from Guatemala, seized pending forfeiture proceedings
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals: Federal court reviewing sentences for legality and reasonableness, with authority to remand cases for further sentencing proceedings
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Commission Guid: Guidelines for federal sentencing, providing a framework for evaluating the fairness and appropriateness of sentences for individual offenders
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: Federal court imposing sentences, with judges considering all relevant factors in a case to impose a sentence outside the guidelines if necessary
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Edward M. Kennedy: United States Senator who described the sentencing guidelines as a comprehensive approach to reduce disparity in punishment
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Congress: Federal legislative body that enacted the sentencing guidelines to ensure fair and uniform sentences
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Senate Report No. 225: Report emphasizing the importance of thoughtful imposition of individualized sentences, highlighting the purpose of sentencing guidelines
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.robbery: crime with a base offense level of 18, used as an example in sentencing guidelines
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Juventino Mejia-Orosco's criminal histor: category assigned based on prior convictions and other factors
